awd_titl_txt: SRS RN Track 2 - Aligning upstream and downstream: increasing equity in watershed management with and for underrepresented communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal is to plan an inclusion and equity framework to improve regional strategies for research, planning, and water resource management thereby increasing effective cross-community and cross-stakeholder water resources stewardship for the Passaic River Basin (PRB). This project is working with “upstream” Munsee Lunaape Elders and with “downstream” disenfranchised communities, notably African American and pan-Latin American neighborhoods in Newark (and Greater Newark) to promote the values of equity and environmental justice. The Passaic River flows through Northern New Jersey and Southeastern New York State encompassing ten counties, and numerous urban and peri urban municipalities. This region was among the earliest US industrial centers, based on a combination of waterpower, water supply, estuarine ports, all adjacent to rapidly expanding New Yor City. Over time these activities resulted in pollution of the urban water supply and consequent shift of water supply to areas further upstream to areas within the basin.   As a result of this pollution, the Ramapough Turtle Clan settlement at Upper Ringwood has been twice-designated Superfund site.  2020 EPA studies have confirmed the ongoing danger.  Dangerous pollution within the basin, disinvestment, and decline of industry have left the PRB communities with high proportions of disadvantaged peoples living and working in toxic and vulnerable sites. In the Newark area, pollution sources include water pollutants of the entire Basin upstream impacting reservoirs. Downstream industrial pollutants include dioxin discharges from a facility making herbicides, used in making Agent Orange, and lead pipes.   The vision in this project is to enhance sustainability of the PRB and its environs through an inclusive approach that engages the disadvantaged communities and other stakeholders in PRB leading to remediation activities to restore the water quality and improve quality of life for the entire community.
 
While the PRB upstream and downstream communities had little prior interconnection, they are interlinked by the area’s growing urban centers that depend on the Passaic River Basin for water supply. Aligning upstream and downstream communities will: a) develop a community of practice centered on equity; b) enable asset mapping of water system members; c) promote relationships of co-learning; and d) develop a participatory, sustainable, equity-led approach. It is this combination of shared interest in good water quality and addressing past exclusions that provide an opportunity for collaborative learning and shared development of approaches, notably interlinked via The Price Institute with the Rutgers School of Environmental and Biological Sciences (SEBS), with their Cooperative Extension (NJAES). This planning grant will begin to cultivate a culture of stewardship among and between local communities and interests for the health and sustainability of the water system and ongoing connection to regional leaders. During implementation, historically marginalized communities will increase knowledge and application of water science, engagement, and public resource stewardship. More local research involvement for more data inputs and insights will also improve the accuracy, nuance, and understanding of the PRB. A community of shared research interests will promote an ethic of greater equity and inclusion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, The Clement A. Price Institute at Rutgers University-Newark initiated a planning process to increase equity and climate resilience with and for underrepresented communities in the greater Passaic River watershed of Northern New Jersey. 'Aligning Upstream & Downstream,' which has grown into the regional multi-stakeholder Passaic Watershed Project (PWP), was funded by a planning grant from the National Science Foundation�s Sustainable Regional Systems (NSF-SRS) program. NSF-SRS funding leverages, complements, enhances and accelerates ongoing initiatives of the Price Institute, founded in 1997, with the belief that the arts and humanities in all their creativity and scholarly rigor have a central role to play in the continued revitalization of Greater Newark; the Institute is especially focused on the history of African Americans in the region and in New Jersey, and the legacy of systemic anti-Black racism.

Working closely with local organizations, associations, networks and individuals, we have identified the scope of disconnections enabled by long-established boundaries and practices within the greater Passaic River Watershed, and articulated problems and opportunities for which the Price Institute could play a bridging role. Engaging historically disenfranchised communities; considering the watershed as an eco-region; and defining ecosystem as encompassing social, cultural, industrial, economic and natural processes within it, our planning grant goals have been to:

  1. Foster sustainable, equitable & inclusive regionally scaled ecosystem stewardship

  2. Conduct an initial asset mapping of associations, community organizations, leaders residents & essential knowledge within the region�s communities

  3. Begin a watershed-scaled & community-oriented co-learning process

  4. Incubate learning, planning & implementation of attainable results & a pathway to nature-based solutions and longer-term resilience.

Together, these goals informed the development of a method, theory of engagement, research propositions & a test bed for implementation, which constitute key outcomes of this planning process.

Through community conversations held upstream (Ringwood), midstream (Paterson) and downstream (Newark), a transect that cuts across rural, peri-urban & urban areas, we engaged over 600 people�experts in their communities�who shared with us urgent matters related to the functioning and future of the ecosystem, watershed & foodshed in which they live. In return, we shared eco-regional research & engaged in roundtable discussions to create opportunities for listening, sharing & learning. Among the participants were Indigenous elders of the Turtle Clan, Ramapough Lenape Nation, who have been trying for decades to protect the land and waters that sustain life in Northern New Jersey.�Some of the many urgent matters raised include:

  • Concern expressed by Newark residents about whether the capping of dangerous chemicals in the bed of of the lower Passaic River would be effective;
  • Paterson residents sick and tired of their basements, schools and streets being flooded with sewage after heavy rainfalls; and
  • Upper Ringwood residents wanting to know if anyone else cared about their community dying of poisonous toxins dumped on their land from the Ford Motor Assembly Plant in Mahwah, near the headwaters of streams and reservoirs supplying drinking water for millions downstream.

Joining these matters together within the frame of the greater Passaic Watershed eco-region would leverage what appear to be isolated efforts into interrelated historical and region-wide challenges & opportunities. In the process of our planning research, it became clear:

  • There are many hidden local assets that can contribute to addressing the challenges local communities face.

  • These local challenges are insufficiently handled by the old practices and old systems which were not sustainable nor ecologically framed.

  • �Local governance is unable to respond effectively and NJ-wide policies are too blunt an instrument to get at eco-regional realities.

  • �Universities are hyper-specialized and need better ways to learn from and collaborate with local communities, municipalities and counties.

  • Understanding the deep ecological history of the region can bring us together and help us better imagine and better formulate better solutions.

Using an ABCD (Asset-Based Community Development) methodology, our�approach to community engagement is not unique. The theory of engagement we have developed though this planning process, however, can offer insights for other eco-regions:

  • The more transparent the change options presented, the greater the participation in �planning�

  • The more studies are designed with community needs in mind, the more insightful their contributions

  • The more local-framed the potential interventions, the greater the interest in co-designing and co-producing the interventions

  • The more urgent the issue is understood to be, the greater the potential support for the necessary investments and implementation

  • The greater the community co-benefits to accompany ecosystem benefits, the more resilient the resulting solutions at the community and regional scales

Working together and organizing ourselves, we believe the PWP gives us all a better chance to protect and regenerate the ecosystems we love and depend on, begin a watershed-scaled community co-learning process, and gain attainable results and a pathway to the implementation of nature-based solutions for longer-term resilience at this eco-regional scale.

�


Last Modified: 03/30/2024
Modified by: John K Tchen

Images (1 of )
  • A map of the greater Passaic River Watershed shows the spatial relationship of the focal areas of our Passaic Watershed Project (PWP) to water resources
    Kerry Hardy, Public History Project
    Copyrighted
    John K Tchen
    The greater Passaic River watershed
  • Elders of the Ramapough Lenape Nation welcomed us, along with residents of the surrounding communities, into a conversation about land and water contamination at the Ringwood Mines Superfund site, and local efforts to fight pollution and ecological injustice.
    The Price Institute
    Copyrighted
    John K Tchen
    The Upstream Community Conversation in Ringwood
  • Over 100 people came out to participate on our Newark Community Conversation. Our "listen first" approach has enabled us to develop a methodology and plan for implementation that responds to local needs, assets and interests.
    The Price Institute
    Copyrighted
    John K Tchen
    Community Conversations listening sessions identified clear and consistent community concerns and a desire to collaborate with other watershed communities
  • A Passaic River Basin model was developed by students in the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) Urban Design Studio, �The Passaic Watershed: Strategic Spatial Frameworks and Tactical Priority Projects,� led by Prof. Georgeen Theodore.
    Georgeen Theodore
    Copyrighted
    John K Tchen
    A model of the Passaic River Basin created by NJIT students informed the Community Conversation in Paterson

In 2022, The Clement A. Price Institute at Rutgers University-Newark initiated a planning process to increase equity and climate resilience with and for underrepresented communities in the greater Passaic River watershed of Northern New Jersey. 'Aligning Upstream & Downstream,' which has grown into the regional multi-stakeholder Passaic Watershed Project (PWP), was funded by a planning grant from the National Science Foundation�s Sustainable Regional Systems (NSF-SRS) program. NSF-SRS funding leverages, complements, enhances and accelerates ongoing initiatives of the Price Institute, founded in 1997, with the belief that the arts and humanities in all their creativity and scholarly rigor have a central role to play in the continued revitalization of Greater Newark; the Institute is especially focused on the history of African Americans in the region and in New Jersey, and the legacy of systemic anti-Black racism.


Working closely with local organizations, associations, networks and individuals, we have identified the scope of disconnections enabled by long-established boundaries and practices within the greater Passaic River Watershed, and articulated problems and opportunities for which the Price Institute could play a bridging role. Engaging historically disenfranchised communities; considering the watershed as an eco-region; and defining ecosystem as encompassing social, cultural, industrial, economic and natural processes within it, our planning grant goals have been to:




Foster sustainable, equitable & inclusive regionally scaled ecosystem stewardship




Conduct an initial asset mapping of associations, community organizations, leaders residents & essential knowledge within the region�s communities




Begin a watershed-scaled & community-oriented co-learning process




Incubate learning, planning & implementation of attainable results & a pathway to nature-based solutions and longer-term resilience.




Together, these goals informed the development of a method, theory of engagement, research propositions & a test bed for implementation, which constitute key outcomes of this planning process.


Through community conversations held upstream (Ringwood), midstream (Paterson) and downstream (Newark), a transect that cuts across rural, peri-urban & urban areas, we engaged over 600 people�experts in their communities�who shared with us urgent matters related to the functioning and future of the ecosystem, watershed & foodshed in which they live. In return, we shared eco-regional research & engaged in roundtable discussions to create opportunities for listening, sharing & learning. Concern expressed by Newark residents about whether the capping of dangerous chemicals in the bed of of the lower Passaic River would be effective;
Paterson residents sick and tired of their basements, schools and streets being flooded with sewage after heavy rainfalls; and
Upper Ringwood residents wanting to know if anyone else cared about their community dying of poisonous toxins dumped on their land from the Ford Motor Assembly Plant in Mahwah, near the headwaters of streams and reservoirs supplying drinking water for millions downstream.



Joining these matters together within the frame of the greater Passaic Watershed eco-region would leverage what appear to be isolated efforts into interrelated historical and region-wide challenges & opportunities. In the process of our planning research, it became clear:




There are many hidden local assets that can contribute to addressing the challenges local communities face.




These local challenges are insufficiently handled by the old practices and old systems which were not sustainable nor ecologically framed.




�Local governance is unable to respond effectively and NJ-wide policies are too blunt an instrument to get at eco-regional realities.




�Universities are hyper-specialized and need better ways to learn from and collaborate with local communities, municipalities and counties.




Understanding the deep ecological history of the region can bring us together and help us better imagine and better formulate better solutions.




Using an ABCD (Asset-Based Community Development) methodology, our�approach to community engagement is not unique. The theory of engagement we have developed though this planning process, however, can offer insights for other eco-regions:




The more transparent the change options presented, the greater the participation in �planning�




The more studies are designed with community needs in mind, the more insightful their contributions




The more local-framed the potential interventions, the greater the interest in co-designing and co-producing the interventions




The more urgent the issue is understood to be, the greater the potential support for the necessary investments and implementation




The greater the community co-benefits to accompany ecosystem benefits, the more resilient the resulting solutions at the community and regional scales




Working together and organizing ourselves, we believe the PWP gives us all a better chance to protect and regenerate the ecosystems we love and depend on, begin a watershed-scaled community co-learning process, and gain attainable results and a pathway to the implementation of nature-based solutions for longer-term resilience at this eco-regional scale.
